# Rani Gaidinliu

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

Rani Gaidinliu  
---  
[![Gaidinliu.jpg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Gaidinliu.jpg/220px-
Gaidinliu.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gaidinliu.jpg) A painting of Gaidinliu  
Born | (1915-01-26)26 January 1915  
Nungkao, [Manipur](/wiki/Manipur_\(princely_state\) "Manipur \(princely
state\)"), British India  
Died | 17 February 1993(1993-02-17) (aged 78)  
Longkao, [Manipur](/wiki/Manipur "Manipur"), India  
Nationality | Indian  
Other names | Gaidiliu  
Occupation | Spiritual and political leader of the [Zeliangrong](/wiki/Zeliangrong "Zeliangrong") [Nagas](/wiki/Naga_people "Naga people")  
Known for | Armed resistance against the [British Raj](/wiki/British_Raj "British Raj")  
  
**Gaidinliu** (1915–1993) was a [Naga](/wiki/Naga_people "Naga people")
spiritual and political leader who led a revolt against [British
rule](/wiki/British_rule_in_India "British rule in India") in
[India](/wiki/India "India").[1] At the age of 13, she joined the
[Heraka](/wiki/Heraka "Heraka") religious movement of her cousin [Haipou
Jadonang](/wiki/Haipou_Jadonang "Haipou Jadonang"). The movement later turned
into a political movement seeking to drive out the British from
[Manipur](/wiki/Manipur "Manipur") and the surrounding
[Naga](/wiki/Naga_people "Naga people") areas. Within the Heraka faith, she
came to be considered an incarnation of the Goddess Cherachamdinliu.[2]
Gaidinliu was arrested in 1932 at the age of 16, and was sentenced to life
imprisonment by the British rulers. [Jawaharlal Nehru](/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru
"Jawaharlal Nehru") met her at Shillong Jail in 1937, and promised to pursue
her release. Nehru gave her the title of "Rani" ("Queen"), and she gained
local popularity as **Rani Gaidinliu**.

She was released in 1947 after [India's independence](/wiki/Partition_of_India
"Partition of India"), and continued to work for the upliftment of her people.
An advocate of the ancestral Naga religious practices, she staunchly resisted
the conversion of Nagas to Christianity. She was honoured as a freedom fighter
and was awarded a [Padma Bhushan](/wiki/Padma_Bhushan "Padma Bhushan") by the
Government of India.

## Early life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rani_Gaidinliu&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Early life")]

Gaidinliu was born on 26 January 1915 at Nungkao (or Longkao) village in the
present-day Tousem sub-division of [Tamenglong
District](/wiki/Tamenglong_District "Tamenglong District"), Manipur. She was
from the [Rongmei](/wiki/Rongmei "Rongmei") tribe (also known as Kabui). She
was the fifth of eight children, including six sisters and a younger brother,
born to Lothonang Pamei and Kachaklenliu.[3] The family belonged to the ruling
clan of the village.[4] She did not have a formal education due to the lack of
schools in the area.[5]

## As Haipou Jadonang's
disciple[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rani_Gaidinliu&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: As Haipou Jadonang's disciple")]

In 1927, when she was just 13, Gaidinliu joined the _[Heraka](/wiki/Heraka
"Heraka")_ movement of her cousin [Haipou Jadonang](/wiki/Haipou_Jadonang
"Haipou Jadonang"), who had emerged as a prominent local leader. Jadonang's
movement was a revival of the Naga tribal religion. It also aimed to end the
British rule and establish the self-rule of the Nagas (_Naga Raj_). It
attracted a number of followers from the Zeliangrong tribes (the
[Zeme](/wiki/Zeme_Naga "Zeme Naga"), [Liangmai](/wiki/Liangmei_Naga "Liangmei
Naga") and [Rongmei](/wiki/Rongmei_Naga "Rongmei Naga")). With the arrival of
guns from [Cachar](/wiki/Cachar "Cachar"), it turned into an armed rebellion
against the British policies of forced labour and ruthless oppression.

Persuaded by Jadonang's ideology and principles, Gaidinliu became his disciple
and a part of his movement against the British. In three years, by the age of
16, she became a leader of [guerrilla](/wiki/Guerrilla_warfare "Guerrilla
warfare") forces fighting against the British rulers.

## Rebellion and
incarceration[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rani_Gaidinliu&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Rebellion and incarceration")]

After Jadonang was arrested and hanged by the British in 1931, Gaidinliu
emerged as his spiritual and political heir.[6]

She openly rebelled against the British rule, exhorting the Zeliangrong people
not to pay taxes. She received donations from the local Nagas, many of whom
also joined her as volunteers. The British authorities launched a manhunt for
her. She evaded arrest by the police, moving across villages in what are now
Assam, Nagaland and Manipur. The Governor of [Assam](/wiki/Colonial_Assam
"Colonial Assam") dispatched the 3rd and 4th battalions of the [Assam
Rifles](/wiki/Assam_Rifles "Assam Rifles") against her, under the supervision
of the [Naga Hills](/wiki/Naga_Hills_District,_British_India "Naga Hills
District, British India") Deputy Commissioner JP Mills. Monetary rewards were
declared for information leading to her arrest: this included a declaration
that any village providing information on her whereabouts will get a 10-year
tax break. Her forces engaged the Assam Rifles in armed conflicts in the North
Cachar Hills (16 February 1932) and the Hangrum village (18 March 1932).

In October 1932, Gaidinliu moved to the Pulomi village, where her followers
started building a wooden fortress. While the fortress was under construction,
an Assam Rifles contingent headed by Captain MacDonald launched a surprise
attack on the village on 17 October 1932. Gaidinliu, along with her followers,
was arrested without any resistance near the Kenoma village. Gaidinliu denied
that she had any role in the attack on the Hangrum post of the Assam Rifles or
the construction of the fort.[2] In December 1932, her followers from the Leng
and the Bopungwemi villages murdered the [Kuki](/wiki/Kuki_people "Kuki
people") [chowkidar](/wiki/Chowkidar "Chowkidar") (watchman) of the Lakema
Inspection Bungalow in the Naga Hills, suspecting him to be the informer who
led to her arrest. Gaidinliu was taken to [Imphal](/wiki/Imphal "Imphal"),
where she was convicted on the charges of murder and abetment of murder after
a 10-month trial. She was sentenced to [life
imprisonment](/wiki/Life_imprisonment "Life imprisonment") by the Political
Agent's Court for abetment of murder.[7] Most of her associates were either
executed or jailed.[5]

From 1933 to 1947 she served time at the [Guwahati](/wiki/Guwahati
"Guwahati"), [Shillong](/wiki/Shillong "Shillong"), [Aizawl](/wiki/Aizawl
"Aizawl") and [Tura](/wiki/Tura,_Meghalaya "Tura, Meghalaya") jails. Many
rebels proclaimed her and Jadonang to be their inspiration in refusing to pay
taxes to the British. However, her movement declined after the last of her
followers, Dikeo and Ramjo, were arrested in 1933. [Jawaharlal
Nehru](/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru "Jawaharlal Nehru") met her at the Shillong Jail
in 1937 and he promised to pursue her release. His statement, published in the
[Hindustan Times](/wiki/Hindustan_Times "Hindustan Times"), described
Gaidinliu as a daughter of the hills and he gave her the title 'Rani' or Queen
of her people. Nehru wrote to the British [MP](/wiki/Member_of_Parliament
"Member of Parliament") [Lady Astor](/wiki/Nancy_Astor,_Viscountess_Astor
"Nancy Astor, Viscountess Astor") to do something for the release of Rani
Gaidinliu but the [Secretary of State for
India](/wiki/Secretary_of_State_for_India "Secretary of State for India")
rejected her request stating that trouble may rise again if Rani was released.

## Life in independent
India[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rani_Gaidinliu&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Life in independent India")]

After the [Interim Government of India](/wiki/Interim_Government_of_India
"Interim Government of India") was set up in 1946, Rani Gaidinliu was released
on [Prime Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_India "Prime Minister of India")
Nehru's orders from Tura jail, having spent 14 years in various prisons. She
continued to work for the upliftment of her people after her release. She
stayed at Vimrap village of [Tuensang](/wiki/Tuensang "Tuensang") with her
younger brother Marang till 1952. In 1952, she was finally allowed to move
back to her native village of Longkao. In 1953, Prime Minister Nehru visited
Imphal where Rani Gaidinliu met and conveyed to him the gratitude and goodwill
of her people. Later she met Nehru in [Delhi](/wiki/Delhi "Delhi") to discuss
the development and welfare of Zeliangrong people.

Gaidinliu was opposed to the [Naga National
Council](/wiki/Naga_National_Council "Naga National Council") (NNC)
insurgents, who advocated secessionism from India. Instead, she campaigned for
a separate Zeliangrong territory within the Union of India.[2]:147 The rebel
Naga leaders criticized Gaidinliu’s movement for the integration of
Zeliangrong tribes under one administrative unit. They were also opposed to
her working for the revival of the traditional Naga religion of animism or
_[Heraka](/wiki/Heraka "Heraka")_. The NNC leaders considered her actions an
obstacle to their own movement. The
[Baptist](/wiki/Nagaland_Baptist_Church_Council "Nagaland Baptist Church
Council") leaders deemed the _Heraka_ revival movement anti-Christian and she
was warned of serious consequences if she were not to change her stand. In
order to defend the _Heraka_ culture and to strengthen her position, she went
underground in 1960.[8] She organized a private army of about a thousand men
equipped rifles to defend and press for her demand for a single [Zeliangrong
district](/wiki/Zeliangrong "Zeliangrong"). In response to
[Phizo](/wiki/Angami_Zapu_Phizo "Angami Zapu Phizo")'s declaration of the
"Naga Federal Government", she set up her own quasi-administration named the
"Zeliangrong Government of Rani Party". In 1964, the overground Zeliangrong
leaders in consultation with underground leaders led by Rani Gaidinliu,
demanded "a separate Zeliangrong Administrative Unit or Political Unit" within
the [Union of India](/wiki/Union_of_India "Union of India"). On 29 January
1965, her followers kidnapped and killed nine Naga rebels from the Ngulong
village of the Kohima district, causing great uproar.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

In 1966, after six years of hard underground life in old age, under an
agreement with the [Government of India](/wiki/Government_of_India "Government
of India"), Rani Gaidinliu came out from her jungle hideout to work for the
betterment of her people through peaceful, democratic and non-violent means.
She went to Kohima on 20 January 1966, and met the Prime Minister Lal Bahadur
Shastri in Delhi on 21 February 1966, demanding the creation of a separate
Zeliangrong administrative unit. On 24 September 320 of her followers
surrendered at Henima. Some of them were absorbed into the [Nagaland Armed
Police](/wiki/Nagaland_Police "Nagaland Police").

During her stay at [Kohima](/wiki/Kohima "Kohima"), she was conferred
"Tamrapatra Freedom Fighter Award" in 1972, the [Padma
Bhushan](/wiki/Padma_Bhushan "Padma Bhushan") (1982)[9] and the [Vivekananda
Seva Award](/wiki/Swami_Vivekananda "Swami Vivekananda") (1983).

## Death[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rani_Gaidinliu&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Death")]

In 1991, Gaidinliu returned to her birthplace Longkao, where she died on 17
February 1993 at the age of 78.[10][11]

The [Governor of Manipur](/wiki/Governor_of_Manipur "Governor of Manipur"),
[Chintamani Panigrahi](/wiki/Chintamani_Panigrahi "Chintamani Panigrahi"), the
Home Secretary of Nagaland, officials from Manipur and many people from all
parts of the [North Eastern region](/wiki/North-East_India "North-East India")
attended her funeral at her native village. In Imphal, the [Chief Minister of
Manipur](/wiki/Chief_Minister_of_Manipur "Chief Minister of Manipur") R.K.
Dorendro Singh, Deputy Chief Minister, [Rishang
Keishing](/wiki/Rishang_Keishing "Rishang Keishing") and others paid floral
tributes and a general holiday was declared by the [State
Government](/wiki/Government_of_Manipur "Government of Manipur").

Rani Gaidinliu was also conferred the _[Birsa Munda](/wiki/Birsa_Munda "Birsa
Munda") Award_ posthumously. The [Government of
India](/wiki/Government_of_India "Government of India") issued a postal stamp
in her honour in 1996.[5][12]The Government of India issued a commemorative
coin in her honour in 2015.[13]

## Legacy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rani_Gaidinliu&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Legacy")]

Because of the Heraka movement's hostility towards Christianity, Gaidinliu's
heroics were not acknowledged highly among the Nagas, most of whom had
converted to Christianity by the 1960s. The [Naga
nationalist](/wiki/Naga_nationalism "Naga nationalism") groups don't recognize
her either, because she was considered close to the Government of India. When
the Hindu nationalist [Sangh Parivar](/wiki/Sangh_Parivar "Sangh Parivar")
aligned with the Heraka movement in the 1970s, the perception that she was a
promoter of Hinduism grew stronger among the Christian Nagas.[14]

In 2015, when the Central government and [T. R. Zeliang](/wiki/T._R._Zeliang
"T. R. Zeliang")'s state government decided to construct a Gaidinliu memorial
hall, several civil society organizations in the [Nagaland](/wiki/Nagaland
"Nagaland") state opposed the move.[15]
